block.documentation:
The Software Subsystem forms the operational backbone of the AOMS, orchestrating the interactions between various hardware components, managing communication with ground control, and enabling autonomous decision-making. The Mission Software component coordinates high-level operational tasks, ensuring that all systems function in concert to meet mission objectives. It manages long-term schedules, adjusts for changing environmental conditions, and prioritizes actions like material resupply, production runs, and data transmission back to Earth. Meanwhile, the Flight Software governs more immediate tasks, including power distribution, propulsion, and data handling, all while continuously monitoring system health.
A key aspect of the Software Subsystem is its ability to handle complex interactions between the different subsystems. Specialized control software such as the Process Control CSC (for manufacturing), the Defect Detection CSC (for quality assurance), and the Fault Management CSC (for system health) are integral to ensuring that the spacecraft operates smoothly and autonomously. The Fault Management CSC is particularly crucial, as it allows the system to detect, isolate, and respond to errors or anomalies without requiring immediate human intervention, thereby improving system resilience and reducing downtime.
